Graphical abstract In this work, a series of Cu- and/or Zn-modified alumina-supported CrOx catalysts have been synthesized by wetness impregnation method and characterized using the combined techniques, including Raman spectroscopy, UV–vis DR, XRD, XRF, H2-TPR and low-temperature N2 sorption, to reveal the effect of the modifiers on the catalyst performance in a fixed-bed isobutane dehydrogenation into isobutylene. The Zn-based modifier is shown to decrease the reducibility of the supported chromium species and reduce the stability of the redox ones, which results in the decreased catalyst activity in isobutane dehydrogenation. The Cu-based modifier on the contrary facilitates the formation of high amount of redox chromium species that leads to the activity growth. The modification by both Cu- and Zn-based modifiers provides an enhanced catalyst performance caused by the synergistic effect of the modifiers and chromium species. The incorporation of the modifiers into alumina support facilitates the formation of the surface defective spinel phases that prevent the incorporation of chromium into the alumina surface and establish the conditions to form the high amount of the active redox chromium species. Keywords Dehydrogenation CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst Chromium species Isobutane Modifiers Cu Zn 1 Introduction For several decades, the dehydrogenation of light paraffins have been bringing about a vivid interest from both academia and industry [1–9], with the industrial implementations comprising both fixed- or fluid-bed reactor systems [10]. The products of such processes, including isobutylene and other olefins, are in-demand chemicals of industrial significance that find various applications in the polymer, chemical, oil-and-gas and other branches of industry. Isobutane dehydrogenation is carried out over various catalytic materials (the catalysts based on Cr [11–20], Pt–Sn [21], Mo [22], carbon [23], metals incorporated into the structure of ordered mesoporous materials (e.g., SBA-15 [24,25], MCM-41 [26–28], metal-organic frameworks [29]), etc., with the CrOx-based composites demonstrating the highest catalyst performance due to their high catalytic activity and selectivity towards isobutylene as well as high stability and durability under the conditions of the dehydrogenation reaction. In industry the alumina-supported chromium oxide catalysts are used for isobutane dehydrogenation [10,30,31]. The use of γ-Al2O3 as a support is caused by its high surface area that allows stabilizing the active component in the required dispersion state and preventing its agglomeration under the high-temperature reaction conditions [6,7,31,32]. This support also stabilizes the surface Cr ions in a high-valence state (Cr(VI)) [33,34] in the initial chromia-alumina catalysts to form the active sites for conversion of light hydrocarbons. Several chromium species were shown to form over the surface of CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts during the catalyst preparation: the redox Cr(VI) species that can be mononuclear chromium species or chemically bonded with alumina [7]; the Cr(III) species including non-redox and redox Cr3+ sites that can be oxidized into different species (i.e., Cr(V) and Cr(VI)) during the regeneration process; amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3 clusters with different sizes [4,6,33]; and the Cr2+ species [35,36]. Under high-temperature process conditions, the agglomeration of the active component into low-activity α-Cr2O3 takes place, and new approaches to stabilize the highly-dispersed active chromium species are required. High requirements to the catalyst performance involve the application of various modifiers [37,38]. Introduction of the modifiers allows controlling a number of the basic characteristics, including acidity (modifiers based on compounds of Na, K, Ca, Cs, etc.), stabilization of active component on the catalyst surface (modifiers based on compounds of Zr, Fe, Si), its phase composition as well as the phase composition of the supports that are used to improve the strength properties of the catalysts [39–44]. Recently, an interest was attracted to the Cu- and Zn-based modifiers that are known to be the catalyst components in several catalytic processes: methanol reforming [45,46], dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol [47], hydrogenation of esters [48], CO oxidation [49], methanol synthesis [50], etc. In our previous work [51] we have shown that the method of introduction of the modifiers determines their distribution and state in the final catalysts as well as the state of chromium component, with the catalysts prepared by sequential impregnation of Cu- and Zn-containing modifiers and chromium precursor showing the highest activity in isobutane dehydrogenation and high selectivity towards isobutylene formation. The formation of Cu and Zn aluminates or defective spinels on the alumina surface was proposed. The modified support surface facilitated the formation and stabilization of redox Cr(VI) sites. The aim of the present work is to provide new insights on the effect of Cu- or Zn- and Cu–Zn-based modifiers for alumina-supported CrOx catalysts in a fixed-bed isobutane dehydrogenation into isobutylene. To reveal the effects of Cu and Zn on the catalyst performance we have prepared a series of supports modified by only Cu or Zn or by both modifiers as well as a series of the catalysts on the basis thereof. All samples were tested under equal conditions and characterized by low-temperature N2 sorption, XRD, XRF, H2-TPR, UV–vis DR, and Raman spectroscopy methods. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of supports and catalysts Pseudoboehmite (AlO(OH)) was used as a precursor to prepare the support. The alumina-based supports were prepared by the impregnation of AlO(OH) with an aqueous solution of Cu(NO3)2*3H2O (99%, “ACROS organics”) and/or Zn(NO3)2*6H2O (99%, “ACROS organics”) at a pH of 3-4. A nominal loading of the components in the supports was 3.5%wt. for Cu and 3.5%wt. for Zn. The synthesized samples were dried at 170 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 500 °C for 6 h. Thus, several series of supports were synthesized, namely, Cu-containing ( Cu/Al2O3 ), Zn-containing ( Zn/Al2O3 ), Cu- and Zn-containing ( Cu-Zn/Al2O3 ), and the ( Al2O3 ). The series of alumina-chromia catalysts were prepared by impregnation of the modified supports and Al2O3 with an aqueous solution of CrO3 (chemically pure, “Vecton”, Russia) and KNO3 (chemically pure, “Vecton”, Russia). A nominal loading of the components in the catalysts was 4%wt. for Cr2O3 to provide a monolayer coverage and 0.85%wt. for K2O. The prepared catalysts were dried at 120 °C for 12 h and then calcined in air at 700 °C for 5 h. 2.2 Characterization of supports and catalysts Chemical analysis of the modified and unmodified supports and the catalysts on the basis thereof was carried out using the XRF-1800 sequential X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer (Shimadzu, Japan). The porous structure of the samples was studied by low-temperature N2 sorption (TriStar 3020 analyzer, Micromeritics, USA) using a multipoint BET method for specific surface area calculations and BJH-desorption method to plot the pore size distributions. The influence of modifiers on the phase transition of pseudoboehmite into Al2O3 was studied by synchronic thermal analysis (TG-DSC-MS) using the STA 449 F1 Jupiter analyzer equipped with QMS 403D Aëolos mass-spectrometer (Netzsch, Germany). The samples (5–10 mg) were heated from 30 to up to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in an air atmosphere (10 ml/min Ar +80 ml/min Air). The UV–vis spectroscopy or diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) and powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) were used to characterize the chemical states of the components. The DRS studies were recorded using the Evolution 600 spectrometer with the spectra of barium sulfate as a baseline. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected by a Miniflex 600 diffractometer using a monochromatic CuKα radiation (γ = 1.5418 Å). The phase composition was analyzed using the PCPDFWIN database. Raman spectra (RS) were taken at ambient conditions using the inVia confocal Raman microscope (Renishaw, UK). The samples were excited with the 785 nm line. The reducibility of the supports, as-prepared catalysts, and the catalysts after the catalytic reaction was studied by the temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR). The measurements were carried out using the ChemiSorb 2750 chemisorption analyzer with a thermal-conductive detector (TCD-signal). The samples were heated from the room temperature to up to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10°/min in a flow of argon–hydrogen mixture (10%vol. H2, a flow rate was 20 mL/min). 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic properties of the chromia catalysts were studied in the nonoxidative dehydrogenation of isobutane using the methodology described in Ref. [51]. The catalytic activity measurements during two catalytic cycles were carried out in a fixed-bed tubular quartz reactor (i.d. was 15 mm) at 540 °C and an atmospheric pressure. A gas mixture of 15% of i-C4H10 (pure: 99.9, LLC “Pure gases”, Novosibirsk) in N2 (LLC “Pure gases”, Novosibirsk) was passed through the catalyst bed (V cat ≈ 0.75 cm3, W cat = 400–500 mg). The powder fraction of the catalysts of 0.25-0.5 mm was used to minimize the diffusion limitations and the catalyst was mixed with the quartz powder in the volumetric ratio of 1:2 to minimize the temperature gradients. The total flow rate was 9 l/h (1.35 i-C4H10 /7.65 N2; GHSV =2.700 h−1). The cycle of the test included the oxidative regeneration in an air for 20 min at 650 °C, the reductive activation in a gas mixture of H2(15%)/N2 for 3 min at 590 °C and the dehydrogenation reaction during 18 and 66 min for the first and the second catalytic cycles, respectively. The experimental conditions were selected to achieve the conversion below 15% that was lower than the thermodynamic equilibrium conversion for the isobutane dehydrogenation at 540 °C. The reaction temperature, 540 °C, was sufficiently lower than industrial operation, in order to suppress carbon deposition and minimize the catalyst deactivation. The gaseous reaction products were analyzed using the online gas chromatograph “Chromatec-Crystall 5000.2” with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), two flame ionization detectors (FID), and a Varian Capillary Column CP-Al2O3/Na2SO4 (50 m, 130 °C). The material balances of carbon were above 97% in all experiments. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Sample characterization 3.1.1 Textural properties The porous structure of the synthesized supports and catalysts was studied by low-temperature N2 adsorption. The obtained adsorption isotherms (Fig. 1 A, B) are characterized by the presence of a hysteresis loop in the range of relative pressures of 0.5–1.0 indicating a mesoporous structure of the synthesized supports and catalysts (H4 type). The pore size distribution curves for the supports (Fig. 1C) also show that the porous structure is characterized by the presence of mesopores with sizes of 2–8 nm. The Cu-, Zn- and Cu-Zn-modified Al2O3 supports are characterized by a narrower pore size distribution in comparison with the alumina support. The introduction of the modifiers leads to a shift of pore size distribution in the range of smaller pore sizes, which is connected with the influence of the modifiers on the formation of the porous structure of alumina support due to the phase transition of pseudoboehmite into γ-Al2O3. A significant shift of pore size distribution to the range of wider pore sizes and a decreasing of the pore volume for the catalysts (Fig. 1D) is caused by the higher calcination temperature (700 °C) and filling of pores by chromium species and potassium that has the highest impact in case of the Cu-Zn-modified catalyst. Table 1 summarizes the textural characteristics and chemical composition of the prepared supports and the catalysts on the basis thereof. Introduction of the modifiers increases the specific surface (to up to 233 m2/g) in comparison with the alumina support (207 m2/g). This is connected with a decreasing of pore size distribution in the range of smaller pore sizes and a corresponding decreasing of pore volume (Vpore) and average pore size (Dpore). The introduction of the active component and alkali modifier (chromium and potassium) and a subsequent calcination of the catalysts at 700 °C reduce the specific surface area and the pore volume due to both distribution of components inside the pores of the support and the growth of the alumina support particles at increased calcination temperature in the range from 500 to 700 °C. The results of the XRF indicate that the chemical composition of the catalysts is close to the nominal one. 3.1.2 Thermal analysis To establish the role of Cu and Zn modifiers in the formation of the porous structure of alumina support due to the transformation of pseudoboehmite into γ-Al2O3 the synchronic thermal analysis (TG and DSC) was applied. Fig. 2 shows the data of thermal analysis for pure pseudoboehmite and after impregnation with an aqueous solution of copper and zinc nitrates and after corresponding drying at 170 °C during 12 h. The low-temperature mass loss and the corresponding endothermic peak at 87–94 °C are attributed to desorption of physically bonded water. The mass loss from 250 to 500 °C with an endothermic peak at 381–408 °C is related to the pseudoboehmite transformation into γ-Al2O3 [32]. The mass loss of ˜15% from 200 to 500 °C for pseudoboehmite corresponds to a content of AlOOH phase in the pseudoboehmite close to 100%. It is noteworthy that the introduction of the modifiers shifts the peak of pseudoboehmite transformation into γ-Al2O3 from 408 to 382 °C. The maximal shift of this peak is observed for the Cu-Zn-modified sample. Thus, according to the TG-DSC results, the modifiers facilitate the pseudoboehmite phase transformation into γ-Al2O3 that explains the difference of the porous structure of the modified supports in comparison with the alumina. Probably, the low-temperature shift of phase transformation leads to the formation of closed mesopores with encapsulated water in the samples and increased surface area after the samples are heated to up to 500 °C [52]. 3.1.3 XRD analysis The chemical state of the active component and modifiers supported onto the surface of the synthesized supports was studied by the XRD, UV–vis and Raman spectroscopy methods. Fig. 3A shows the X-ray patterns for the Al2O3, the modified supports and the catalysts on the basis thereof. The reflexes of the γ-Al2O3 (card No. 00-050-0741) phase are observed for all samples, with some differences in the intensity for the reference and modified samples. The absence of reflexes of Cu-, Zn- and Cr-containing phases indicates high dispersion of the introduced components, which complicates the study of the effect of Cu and Zn in details using the XRD method. However, the increased intensity of the reflexes at 2Θ = 31.3 and 36.7°, 60.5 and 66.8° for the Cu- and Zn-modified catalysts may evidence the formation of the phases of spinels CuAl2O4 (card No. 33-0448) and ZnAl2O4 (card No. 05-0669) according to the PCPDFWIN database and literature data [53]. Moreover, Table 2 contains the values of cubic lattice parameters (а) for γ-Al2O3 that increase with the introduction of Cu and Zn. This indicates the incorporation of the ions of the modifiers into the alumina lattice and the formation of the defective spinels. These results are in agreement with the TG-DSC data that show the formation of spinel through the incorporation of Cu and Zn modifiers during the phase transformation of pseudoboehmite into γ-Al2O3. 3.1.4 UV–vis analysis Fig. 4 A shows the UV–vis spectra for the range of 200–900 nm for the prepared supports. There is no adsorption for pure alumina support in the UV–vis region. For the Zn/Al2O3 sample, there is an absorption band in the range of 200–220 nm that is characteristic for ZnO as a semiconductor with a bandgap energy of 3.37 eV [54]. The absorption in the wavelength range of 200–245 nm (a maximal value is at 240 nm) for Cu-containing supports (Cu/Al2O3 and Cu-Zn/Al2O3 ) is attributed to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) band of Cu2+ species with octahedral environment typical for oxides [55,56]. A shoulder in the range of 370 nm (Cu/Al2O3 ) also indicates the LMCT transitions of tetrahedrally coordinated Cu2+ sites which are characteristic for copper aluminates in the form of defective spinel [54], which is in agreement with the XRD results (Fig. 3A). A low-intensity absorption band in the range of 700–800 nm can be connected with the presence of the d–d-transition of isolated Cu2+ species with a tetragonally distorted octahedral environment, and similar absorption bands were observed in Ref. [55] during the investigation of the Cu–Zn–Al–O catalysts. The UV–vis spectra for the fresh catalysts (Fig. 4B) contain the absorption bands at 270 and 370 nm that are attributed to the electron transitions O → Cr6+ [33]. The highest intensities of these peaks for Cu-Zn-modified catalyst indicate the highest content of Cr(VI) species. For the Cu-containing samples, not only the growth of the intensity of the band at 270 nm caused by the increase of the number of Cr(VI) sites, but also the impact of the absorption band at 240 nm (Cu2+). The absence of the absorption in a longwave region (the absorption bands at 468 and 598 nm) and the absence of reflexes of the α-Cr2O3 phase in the XRD patterns evidence the predominant existence of Cr in a hexavalent state. In the range of 445 nm, a low-intensity absorption band characteristic for dichromates [33,34,57] is observed. Thus, the co-introduction of the Cu and Zn modifiers promote the formation of the Cr(VI) species on the catalyst surface. 3.1.5 Raman spectroscopy analysis The detailed studies of the nature of CrOx species on the catalyst surface prior to the catalytic cycle were studied by Raman spectroscopy. The designation of the absorption bands is represented in Table 3 . For all samples, the spectral background connected with the fluorescent ability of the support is observed [58]. According to the literature [4,31], the most intensive bands of Cr sites are located in the range of 600–1100 cm−1. Fig. 5 A shows the Raman spectra for modified supports. According to literature data, the absorption bands in the range of ˜1050–1092 cm−1 observed for Zn/Al2O3 and Cu-Zn/Al2O3 can be attributed to hexagonal ZnO powder [59,60]. For Cu-Zn/Al2O3 support, the absorption band at ˜630 cm−1 characterizes the strong modes of the CuO monoclinic structure formed in the presence of Zn compounds [61]. The absorption band in the range of 773 cm−1 can be assigned to the d–d transitions of Cu2+ in a tetragonally distorted octahedral geometry around Cu2+ ions [62]. The Cu/Al2O3 support is not characterized by the absorbance in the range from 400 to 1200 cm−1 that may indicate the homogeneous distribution of copper in the structure of alumina support without formation of CuO phase. The Raman spectra for catalysts are characterized by intensive vibrations of Cr-containing species in the range of 600–1100 cm−1 (Fig. 5B). The absorption bands at ˜857 cm−1 can be attributed to dimeric chromium (VI) oxide species [63], while the absorption bands at ˜884 cm−1 can be attributed to isolated tetrahedral surface chromate species [3] that are predominant for all catalysts. The amount of monochromia species is the highest for Cu- and Cu-Zn-modified catalysts. A weak vibration at ˜826 cm−1 indicates the formation of a small amount of highly polymerized chromates [6]. A shoulder at ˜780 cm−1 reflects the stretching modes of the bridging Cr–O–Cr units [64,65]. For these catalysts, a shoulder at ˜931 cm−1 can be assigned to terminal CrO3 groups [63]. The band at 986 cm−1 can be connected with the presence of the crystalline forms of CrO3, which are more characteristic for the CrOx/Cu/Al2O3 [63,66]. The dimeric Cr(VI) species (˜857 cm−1) also prevail for this catalyst. It is noteworthy that the absence of the absorption bands at 537 and 600 cm−1 can be attributed to crystalline Cr2O3 nanoparticles with the Cr(III)O bond in the octahedral environment [67]. Thus, according to Raman results, different Cr(VI) species exist on the surface of Al2O3 and modified alumina support. The amount of Cr(VI) species is significantly higher for modified catalysts in comparison with the reference CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst. Mono- and dimeric chromium (VI) oxide species predominate on the surface of as-prepared alumina-chromia catalysts. A small amount of oligomeric and polymeric species is also observed for the catalysts. 3.1.6 H2-TPR analysis Fig. 6 and Table 4 summarize the results of temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen of the supports and catalysts. The initial support γ-Al2O3 and Zn/Al2O3 do not show the reducibility. The profiles for Cu/Al2O3 and Cu-Zn/Al2O3 supports are characterized by the peaks of hydrogen consumption at 315 and 324 °C that may indicate the reduction of Cu2+ from the highly dispersed spinel ((Cu, Zn)Al2O4) [54,55]. This correlates with the XRD (Fig. 3A) and UV–vis (Fig. 4A) data. The as-prepared reference sample CrOx/Al2O3 is characterized by the presence of one hydrogen consumption peak at 407 °C attributed to the reduction of Cr6+ to Cr3+ [13,14,51]. The presence of Zn in the catalyst (CrOx/Zn/Al2O3 ) shifts the peak maximum of Cr reduction towards the higher temperatures and the process is accompanied by the increase of the amount of hydrogen consumed (439 °C, 652 μmol/g). This may be connected with the formation of a larger number of Cr6+ species that are strongly bound to the support surface, which correlate with the UV–vis data (Fig. 4B, ˜370 nm), and an increased intensity of the absorbance in Raman spectra (Fig. 5B). Thus, the addition of Zn modifier leads to both increased temperature of reduction and increased amount of Cr(VI) species. For the CrOx/Cu/Al2O3 catalyst the low-temperature reduction peak at 287 °C and a shoulder at 315 °C evidences the co-reduction of highly dispersed spinel (CuAl2O4) [54,55] and high-valent Cr6+ to up to Cr3+ [6]. This effect may be attributed to the high dispersity of active component existing in the form of dimeric chromium oxide species (Fig. 5B, the band at ˜862 nm). The CrOx/Cu-Zn/Al2O3 catalyst is characterized by two TPR peaks at 287 °C and 340 °C attributed to reduction of Cr6+ and Cu2+ species. Two peaks indicate the formation of two types of chromium species: the first ones are similar to those in the CrOx/Cu/Al2O3 catalyst (TPR peak at 287 °C) and second one is a new type of species connected with the interaction of CrOx with Cu and Zn modifiers. It is noteworthy that the amount of hydrogen consumed for this catalyst is the highest one (825 μmol/g). This indicates the synergistic effect of Cu and Zn modifiers on the stabilization of the active component in the Cr(VI) state, that is also reflected in the UV–vis spectra (absorption bands at 370 and 270 nm) and Raman spectroscopy. 3.2 Catalytic performance The isobutane dehydrogenation into isobutylene was studied in the kinetic mode to prevent the conversion limitation by the thermodynamic equilibrium of dehydrogenation-hydrogenation reactions. Fig. 7 A shows the obtained results of the catalytic experiments as dependencies of the isobutane conversion and isobutylene selectivity during two consequent dehydrogenation cycles with oxidative regeneration and reductive activation between them. The conversion value is presented with the error bars of 5% (relative), which is based on the error of chromatographic analysis. The catalytic experiments were repeated twice, and high reproducibility of data was obtained. The isobutane conversion was used as the main comparison parameter, since close selectivities (97–99 %) were observed for all samples. The C1-C3 hydrocarbons were detected as the main by-products that indicates the insignificant impact of the cracking reaction. The reference CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst shows the highest yield of 0.093 mmol/min*cm3 of the target product on the sixth minute of the second cycle (Fig. 7B) at a selectivity of 97.8% (Fig. 7A). The introduction of Zn into the catalyst (CrOx/Zn/Al2O3 ) decreases the isobutane conversion (Fig. 7A) in comparison with the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst. After the regeneration in the air flow followed by reductive activation, the CrOx/Zn/Al2O3 catalyst shows slightly higher isobutane conversion during the first minutes, and the activity than decreases and does not reach the one for the reference alumina-chromia sample (CrOx/Al2O3 ). Cu-containing catalyst CrOx/Cu/Al2O3 has conversions at the first reaction cycle comparable with the CrOx/Al2O3 (Fig. 7A). The CrOx/Cu/Al2O3 catalyst significantly increases its activity after the redox treatment (isobutane conversion increases from 6.5 to up to 10.0%), and improves the activity (Fig. 7B) as compared to CrOx/Al2O3 that can be connected with the predominance of a number of mononuclear and dimeric chromium oxide species (Fig. 5B). The CrOx/Cu-Zn/Al2O3 catalyst shows higher conversions during both the first and the second cycles as compared to all catalysts (S = 98.5%, X = 11.0%), which evidences the synergistic effect of two Cu and Zn modifiers facilitating the increase of the CrOx activity. The CrOx/Cu-Zn/Al2O3 catalyst keeps the trend of conversion growth at the second cycle and increases its activity during the first several minutes (the isobutylene yield increases from 11.0 to up to 14.2%) followed by an insignificant decrease of isobutane conversion to up to 12.0%, which is still higher than at the first catalytic cycle. The maximal selectivity towards isobutylene also is observed for the Cu-Zn-modified catalysts. Accordingly, the combination of Cu and Zn modifiers promote the growth of both activity and selectivity of the alumina-chromia catalysts. Thus, during the two catalytic cycles a significant change in the activity of the catalysts is observed that indicates a redistribution of active component and modifiers on the catalyst surface. After the second catalytic cycle, the catalysts were cooled down to room temperature in N2 atmosphere without the oxidative regeneration, and the amount of coke was measured by the TG-DSC. No mass loss, exothermic peaks and CO2 evolution at 250–450 °C were observed (not shown) that indicates the absence or small amount of coke on the surfaces of all catalysts. The absence of coke after the dehydrogenation for 66 min is consistent with the high selectivities and may be associated with both relatively low dehydrogenation temperature (540 °C) and high amounts of potassium and other modifiers. Therefore, the deactivation of catalysts during second catalytic cycle is not connected with the coke formation, but with the degradation of active chromia sites, i.e. either aggregation of isolated and oligomeric Cr3+ species into α-Cr2O3 and/or incorporation of Cr into alumina support. To study the active surface of the catalysts after two dehydrogenation cycles, the catalysts were reoxidized at 650 °C and characterized by Raman spectroscopy and TPR-H2 methods. Fig. 5B shows the Raman spectroscopy data for the catalysts after two cycles of isobutane dehydrogenation and the subsequent oxidation in the air flow. For all systems the keeping of the main absorption bands at ˜857, ˜884, ˜930 and ˜986 cm−1 are observed. The CrOx/Al2O3 and CrOx/Zn/Al2O3 catalysts are characterized by a significant intensity reduction as compared to the as-prepared samples that can be connected with a decrease of the amount of hexavalent Cr in the catalysts. The spectra for the CrOx/Cu/Al2O3 and CrOx/Cu-Zn/Al2O3 samples after 2 catalytic cycles changed only slightly that indicates the high stability of these reversible redox Cr(VI) species in the Cu-modified catalysts. The study of the catalyst samples after two catalytic cycles using TPR-H2 method allowed estimating the amount of redox Cr species. For CrOx/Al2O3 and CrOx/Zn/Al2O3 catalysts a 1.5-time lowering of the consumed hydrogen is observed and shows a decrease of the amount of redox Cr species that is in a good agreement with the results of Raman studies. Based on the catalysis data it is possible to assume that the decrease of the redox Cr species in the CrOx/Al2O3 and CrOx/Zn/Al2O3 samples starts at the first minutes of the second cycle, which results in a gradual catalyst deactivation and activity decrease. For Cu-containing catalyst, there are no significant changes in TPR profile after the catalytic cycles. This result indicates the stabilization of redox Cr(VI) species in the presence of copper. The activity of the Cu-modified catalyst is higher in comparison with the reference CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst. The TPR profile for CrOx/Cu-Zn/Al2O3 catalyst insignificantly change for the sample after two catalytic cycles. A narrow TPR peak at 340 °C may be attributed to the reduction of mononuclear chromia species [6], which correlates with a high intensity of the peak at 884 cm−1 in the Raman spectra for this catalyst. Probably, a redistribution of chromium species during the redox cycles in the presence of both Cu and Zn modifiers leads to the additional formation of mononuclear chromium species. The reduction of these mononuclear Cr(VI) species in reductive activation (H2/N2 mixture) prior to the dehydrogenation leads to the formation of high amount of mononuclear Cr3+ sites being one of the most active in the isobutene dehydrogenation according to Fridman et al. [7]. Thus, based on Raman spectroscopy studies and TPR-H2 data it is possible to conclude that the introduction of Cu-based modifiers promotes the increase of the stability of redox Cr species on the catalyst surface as opposed to Zn-based modifiers. According to Fridman et al. [7], the deactivation of the industrial chromia-alumina catalyst of the Catofin process is mainly connected with the agglomeration of the chromium species into inactive α-Cr2O3 and a migration of chromium atoms into the structure of the alumina support. In the present work, we observe both growth of activity and stability of Cu-modified catalysts. The incorporation of copper into the structure of alumina support with the formation of the surface defective spinel leads to an increased amount and enhanced reducibility of Cr (VI) species. The reduction of these species during the reductive pre-treatment before the dehydrogenation may provide the formation of the most active mononuclear Cr (III) sites. In addition, the formation of the surface copper and/or zinc defective spinels prevents the incorporation of Cr into the support structure that additionally provides the catalyst stability. The most active sample is the composite containing both Cu- and Zn-based modifiers. Probably, a synergy between the Cu and Zn modifiers facilitates the formation of the highest amount of active chromium species. The amount and coordination of Cr(III) species depend on the amount and coordination of Cr(VI) species in the oxidized as-prepared catalysts and the peculiarities of their reduction. It can be seen from the TPR results that both Cu and Zn increase the amount of redox Cr(VI) species, with the highest amount such species being observed over the Cu-Zn-modified catalyst. Probably, the incorporation of Cu and Zn into surface of the γ-Al2O3 support increases the amount of redox Cr(VI) species. The surface defective spinels may prevent the incorporation of the chromium atoms into the alumina support. If both Cu and Zn modifiers are used, the competitive incorporation of Cu and Zn occurs and, probably, the formation of mixed Cu-Zn-O structures as in the methanol synthesis catalysts takes place [68,69]. The Raman results indicate both the increased amount of Cr(VI) species and the predominance of the mononuclear Cr(VI) species in the Cu-Zn-modified catalyst. The reduction of Cr(VI) into Cr(III) under mild conditions (TPR results) may keep the coordination of chromium, and very active mononuclear Cr3+ sites may dominate on the surface of the modified catalyst under the reductive conditions of the dehydrogenation process as it is shown in the scheme (Fig. 8 ). It is noteworthy that the high amount of redox chromium species is kept after two catalytic cycles. Therefore, the co-presence of Cu and Zn provides the stability of the mononuclear and dimeric redox Cr(VI)↔Cr(III) species, probably, due to both prevention of the incorporation of chromium atoms into the alumina support and the aggregation into the inactive α-Cr2O3 phase. Thus, the synergy of Cu and Zn modifiers consist in the increasing of the amount and stability of redox mononuclear and dimeric Cr(VI) species that provides the growth of both activity and stability of the catalysts in the isobutane dehydrogenation. 4 Conclusions Thus, the series of Cu- and Zn-modified alumina supports and chromia catalysts on the basis thereof have been synthesized. The Cu- and Cu-Zn-modified catalysts are shown to have higher catalytic activity in isobutane dehydrogenation in comparison with unmodified CrOx/Al2O3 and Zn-modified catalysts. The use of Zn compounds decreases the catalytic activity that may be associated with a decreased reducibility of the supported chromium and low stability of the redox chromium species. The use of Cu compounds facilitates the formation of a higher amount of redox chromium species. A combination of Cu- and Zn-based modifiers gives the synergistic effect and enhances the catalyst performance in the isobutane dehydrogenation. Raman spectroscopy shows that the sample modified by both Cu and Zn predominantly has mononuclear and dimeric Cr(VI) species and their amounts are significantly higher than those for unmodified alumina-chromia catalyst. The combination of the abovementioned factors allows improving the catalytic activity and stability of the alumina-chromia catalysts in isobutane dehydrogenation to isobutylene that is of importance for industrial application. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a series of Cu- and/or Zn-modified alumina-supported CrOx catalysts have been synthesized by wetness impregnation method and characterized using the combined techniques, including Raman spectroscopy, UV–vis DR, XRD, XRF, H2-TPR and low-temperature N2 sorption, to reveal the effect of the modifiers on the catalyst performance in a fixed-bed isobutane dehydrogenation into isobutylene. The Zn-based modifier is shown to decrease the reducibility of the supported chromium species and reduce the stability of the redox ones, which results in the decreased catalyst activity in isobutane dehydrogenation. The Cu-based modifier on the contrary facilitates the formation of high amount of redox chromium species that leads to the activity growth. The modification by both Cu- and Zn-based modifiers provides an enhanced catalyst performance caused by the synergistic effect of the modifiers and chromium species. The incorporation of the modifiers into alumina support facilitates the formation of the surface defective spinel phases that prevent the incorporation of chromium into the alumina surface and establish the conditions to form the high amount of the active redox chromium species.
coredata.dc:title: Synergistic effect of Cu and Zn modifiers on the activity of CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts in isobutane dehydrogenation
